data.text:
Weather in January

January in Russia, the heart of the winter season, is characterized by biting cold temperatures. In the northern and central parts, particularly in the Siberian region, January is the coldest month of the year. The coldest inhabited place on Earth, Oymyakon, located in the eastern part of Russia, frequently sees temperatures plummeting to a chilling -50°C (-58°F) in January.

The central parts of the country, including cities such as Moscow and Saint Petersburg, also experience harsh winters. In Moscow, January temperatures average from -10°C (14°F) to -4°C (24.8°F), while Saint Petersburg sees similar temperatures, from -8°C (17.6°F) to -4°C (24.8°F). Snow cover is a constant throughout the month, adding to the winter charm of these cities.

In contrast, the southern regions such as Sochi near the Black Sea coast have milder winters. January temperatures in Sochi typically range from 2°C (35.6°F) to 9°C (48.2°F), making it one of the warmest places in Russia during this month. However, even these comparatively warmer regions see occasional snowfall.

January stands out as the month with the least amount of sunshine in Russia, owing to shorter daylight hours. For instance, the city of Murmansk, located above the Arctic Circle, experiences a phenomenon called the Polar Night, where the sun does not rise at all for about a month. This lack of sunlight is a unique characteristic of the Russian climate in January.

In terms of precipitation, the majority falls as snow in January across most of Russia, especially in Siberian regions and in the northwestern part of the country. Cities such as Krasnoyarsk in Siberia and Pskov in the northwest observe significant snowfall during this month.

Moving from the extreme cold of January, Russia gradually transitions into slightly milder conditions in February. Nevertheless, January's severe cold weather sets the stage for the continuation of the harsh winter season that has made Russia famous.
